citation.article-title: Ottowia thiooxydans gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel facultatively anaerobic, N2O-producing bacterium isolated from activated sludge, and transfer of Aquaspirillum gracile to Hylemonella gracilis gen. nov., comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Hylemonella gen. nov.
Hylemonella (Hy.le.mo.nel′la. L. dim. ending -ella; N.L. fem. dim. n. Hylemonella of Hylemon, named after Phillip B. Hylemon, who made important contributions to the taxonomy of freshwater spirilla).
The description is essentially based on the work of Hylemon et al. (1973) on Aquaspirillum gracile.
It is supplemented by results obtained in this study and data taken from Sakane & Yokota (1994) and Hamana et al. (1994).
Cells are Gram-negative spirilla of small diameter.
Motile by bipolar tufts of flagella.
No spores or cysts are produced and no coccoid bodies are formed in older cultures.
Pigments are not produced.
Polyhydroxyalkanoates are not stored intracellularly.
Oxidase- and catalase-positive.
No growth at temperatures below 15 or above 42 °C.
Respiratory chemoheterotrophic metabolism.
Growth factors required.
Generally, only carbohydrates are utilized as sole carbon sources.
No anaerobic growth with nitrate.
No aerobic chemolithoautotrophic growth with hydrogen.
Thiosulfate is not oxidized to sulfate.
Major respiratory lipoquinone is ubiquinone 8 (Q-8).
Major cellular fatty acids are 16 : 1, 16 : 0, 18 : 0, 10 : 1 and 17 : 0.
Hydroxylated fatty acids 10 : 0 3-OH and 12 : 0 3-OH are present.
Cells contain the polyamines 2-hydroxyputrescine and putrescine.
Phylogenetically affiliated to the family Comamonadaceae within the β-Proteobacteria.
The type species is Hylemonella gracilis.
